choices.C: R1 and R3 are in the same subnet.
choices.D: PC-A and PC-B are in the same subnet.
choices.B: One of the routers has two connected serial interfaces.
choices.A: The subnet address of PC-B has 18 bits dedicated to the network portion.
choices.E: The subnet of PC-C can contain 256 hosts.

discussion.content: B & D. There can only be 254 hosts in a /24 network

comments.content: YES!! D. PC-A and PC-B are in the same subnet, they are connected by interconnected network switches

discussion.content:
B is 100% correct.
D is the closest answer than others. hosts connected to the same switch DOES NOT mean that they are on the same subnet. Different switch ports can be on different subnets (This is what VLANs are for, breaking down broadcast domains in a switch)
as others already mentioned, a /24 network can only have 254 host addresses

comments.content: Agreed. PC-B could easily be sitting in another VLAN. Option D is vague to the point of absurdity but it's the only option that will satisfy the question( Cisco should know better!) B&D are the best choices.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
B and D are the only one correct
It's B & D, because E can have only 254 hosts.
The correct answers are B & E
B and D. PC A and PC B are in the same LAN segment and the subnet of PC C can has only 254 usable IP addresses.
It should be B and D.
B & D. There can't be 256 hosts in a subnet. Only 254
B & D, as mentioned by pogrywa.
R2 has two serial interfaces. PC-A and PC-B are connected through a switch. B&D.

erratum
B & D are correct,

E is wrong since there can only be 254 hosts on the subnet of PC C since 2 ip addresses must be assigned to network and broadcast address
B & D is the correct answer

comments.content: 1 is network address and the other is the broadcast address, these two are not Hosts. So, only Hosts or usable hosts( if you want to call them like this) : 254. Doesn't exist unusable hosts.

discussion.content:
Total Number of Hosts: 256
Number of Usable Hosts: 254
Answer - B & D

comments.content:
B & D
E is not right because there would be 256 addresses and 254 hosts.

discussion.content: The thing here is, PC-B and PC-A could be on the same subnet (192.168.3.0/24) OR that PC-A and PC-B are on the same subnet (192.168.1.0/24), this is not clear on the picture. Now if we use an IP calculator on PC-C network address, we have 2 raw information, Total Host (256) and total usable host (254). the answer E says 256 hosts, not usable hosts, so E could be right answer, depending on what I mention at the beginning.
B & D are the correct answer

B & D. the CID notation /24 or 255.255.255.0 leave 8 bit for the host and 2 ^ 8 is 256 but you have to minus 2 which reduces to 254 host; The first is the network and the last is the broadcast. so you can not have 256 as the answer
B&D. There can only be 254 hosts in a /24 subnets

B --> because i can see it
D --> because both are connected to the same L2 Switch.
b, d are correct
I agree with pogrywa, B & D, there can only be 254 hosts in a /24 subnet, the fire is the network address and the last is the broadcast address.

Related to the previous question on RESTCONF transport protocol.

comments.content:
Straight from Cisco docs. Obiwan Kenobi is 100% correct (because The Force is with him, folks. I can't believe I even have to tell you this). 

In this day and age, data of a sensitive nature should NEVER be transmitted without a protection layer. Cisco would never knowingly support the exposure of sensitive data, so choices that begin with "http" and don't end with "s" should immediately be thrown out unless you are being directed to identify something *wrong* with the code example. Stop wasting your time deliberating over immutable standards when the answer is so dang obvious. 

Further evidence for secure RESTCONF can be confirmed in RFC8040 section 2.0:
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8040#section-2

Welcome to 2021.

discussion.content:
Should be HTTPS

• RESTCONF— Uses structured data (XML or JSON) and YANG to provide a REST-like APIs, enabling
you to programmatically access different network devices. RESTCONF APIs use HTTPs methods.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/prog/configuration/166/b_166_programmability_cg/restconf_prog_int.pdf

Book Devasc Page 628 Chapter Restconf:

Like other REST APIs, RESTCONF uses the HTTPS protocol to encapsulate and send messages. Authentication is accomplished using typical HTTP authentication models, such as basic authentication, where usernames and passwords are Base64 encoded
and transmitted from the client to the server via an Authentication header.
Correct:
HTTP/2
SSH
HTTPS

HTTP/2 - gRPC
HTTPS - Restconf
SSH - Netconf
provided answer is correct as the transport protocol for RESTCONF is indeed HTTP, it allows for HTTPS but the right answer is regular HTTP.

comments.content: RESTCONF does not uses HTTP as per security recommendations. Here we're talking about Cisco certs and products. None of these use HTTP.
